intro: Tragacantha strobilifera, commonly known as the Persian gum tree, is a flowering plant native to the regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers that bloom in spring. The plant produces a sticky resin, known as tragacanth, which has been historically used in medicine and as a natural gum in various industries. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along dry riverbeds. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for native wildlife.
